content: The Act may be cited as the "Environmental Justice Enforcement Act of 2006". The Act is necessary due to a Supreme Court decision that weakens statutory protections against discrimination established by Congress over almost 4 decades. The decision in Alexander v. Sandoval undermines these protections by denying victims of discrimination the right to sue in Federal court. The Sandoval decision weakens statutory protections against discrimination established by Congress, denying victims the right to sue in Federal court and casting doubt on the validity of regulations. The Sandoval decision undermines protections against discrimination established by Congress, questioning the validity of regulations and impacting the ability to sue in Federal court. Congress enacted title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to prevent federal funding from supporting discriminatory programs based on race, color, or national origin. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 aimed to prevent federal funding from supporting discriminatory programs based on race, color, or national origin. Regulations were put in place to ensure broad protections for beneficiaries, forbidding discrimination and retaliation. The Department of Justice regulations under title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibited discrimination and retaliation, drafted by the same officials involved in creating the Act. These regulations remain valid since 1966. The regulations under title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, drafted by the same officials involved in creating the Act, have never been invalidated. Congress considered but rejected a proposal to invalidate these regulations in 1966, implying their accuracy according to the Supreme Court. Congress considered and rejected a proposal to invalidate the disparate impact regulations under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, implying their accuracy according to the Supreme Court. Title VI was designed to benefit those discriminated against and relied on private attorneys general for enforcement. Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 aimed to benefit those discriminated against and relied on private attorneys general for enforcement, as recognized by Congress and the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court has affirmed that individuals facing discrimination under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 can take legal action in Federal courts, even though Congress did not explicitly grant this right in the statute. This private right of action is deemed necessary for effective protection of the law. The Supreme Court affirmed that individuals facing discrimination under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 have a private right of action in Federal courts, necessary for effective protection of the law. In 1972, Congress established a right to attorney's fees in private actions brought under title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Supreme Court had no legal basis in Sandoval for denying a right of action under regulations promulgated pursuant to title VI while permitting it under the statute. Regulations promulgated under title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 were congressionally mandated and directed by Congress to enforce antidiscrimination provisions. PROHIBITED DISCRIMINATION. Section 601 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is amended to include provisions regarding discrimination based on disparate impact. An aggrieved person must demonstrate that a covered entity has a policy or practice causing a disparate impact on race, color, or national origin. An aggrieved person can file a complaint if a covered entity's policy or practice causes a disparate impact based on race, color, or national origin, and the entity fails to show that it is necessary for nondiscriminatory goals. The covered entity can be held liable if their policy or practice causes a disparate impact based on race, color, or national origin, and they fail to show it is necessary for nondiscriminatory goals. The covered entity can be held liable if their policy or practice causes a disparate impact based on race, color, or national origin, and they fail to show it is necessary for nondiscriminatory goals. The aggrieved person must demonstrate that each challenged policy or practice causes a disparate impact, or show that a less discriminatory alternative exists and the entity refuses to adopt it. The aggrieved person must show that each challenged policy or practice causes a disparate impact, unless the decision-making process cannot be separated for analysis. If a covered entity proves that a specific policy does not cause a disparate impact, they are not required to demonstrate it further. The covered entity's decision-making process may be analyzed as one policy or practice if it cannot be separated for analysis. If a specific policy does not cause a disparate impact, the entity is not required to prove it further. Demonstrating that a policy is necessary for achieving program goals cannot be used as a defense against intentional discrimination claims. No person in the United States shall face discrimination or retaliation for opposing any prohibited policy or practice, or for participating in investigations or hearings related to discrimination. The term 'demonstrates' refers to meeting the burdens of production and persuasion. SEC. 4. RIGHTS OF ACTION. Amends Section 602 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to allow any person aggrieved by a covered entity's failure to comply with the title to bring a civil action in Federal or State court. SEC. 5. RIGHT OF RECOVERY. Amends Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to provide for the right of recovery after section 602. SEC. 5. RIGHT OF RECOVERY. Amends Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to provide for the right of recovery for aggrieved persons. In an action brought under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, an aggrieved person can recover equitable and legal relief for intentional discrimination, including compensatory and punitive damages, attorney's fees, and costs. Punitive damages are not available against government entities. An aggrieved person can recover legal relief for intentional discrimination under Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, including compensatory and punitive damages, attorney's fees, and costs. However, punitive damages are not available against government entities. In cases of disparate impact discrimination, the aggrieved person may only recover equitable relief, attorney's fees, and costs. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments are retroactive to April 24, 2001, and apply to all actions pending on or after that date, except for actions against a State under the disparate impact standard, which have the effective date of the Act's enactment.
